title: 107_hr5254
content: The Act titled "Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2002" provides assistance to families of teacher victims. The Secretary of Education provides assistance to families of teacher victims, including funeral assistance, a death benefit, living assistance, and dependent undergraduate education assistance. Dependent undergraduate education assistance provides up to $7,500 annually for a child enrolled in a program at an institution of higher education, not affecting other federal assistance under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. Dependent child may receive assistance for up to 5 years, contingent on maintaining good standing at the institution. Parental death or remarriage does not impact eligibility for assistance. Tax provisions are introduced for elementary or secondary school staff members killed in an act of violence while performing school duties. Teacher's wages in the year of death are excluded from income under a new section of the Internal Revenue Code. Tax provisions exempt school staff victims from paying taxes on income received in the year of death due to school employment. Tax provisions exempt school staff victims from paying taxes on income received in the year of death due to school employment, including assistance for teacher victim families under section 139 of the Internal Revenue Code. Tax provisions exempt school staff victims from paying taxes on income received in the year of death due to school employment, including assistance for teacher victim families under section 139 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2002 excludes certain amounts from gross income for individuals. Effective from taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, the amendments also include entitlement to Medicare benefits. The surviving spouse and dependent children of a victim can elect to receive Medicare benefits, including hospital insurance under part A and supplementary medical insurance under part B. They may also enroll in a Medicare supplemental policy. The child making an election under subsection (a) is entitled to Medicare benefits until the date of remarriage for a surviving spouse or until the dependent child turns 25. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement this provision and provide enrollment periods under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. SEC. 5 of the Act prohibits any assistance from replacing existing benefits for the victim's family. SEC. 6 provides definitions. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms such as "victim," "surviving spouse," "dependent child," "institution of higher education," and "cost of attendance." The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education as defined in section 472 of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
